transcript:
Therapist: You've made some really important insights, Emilio. Recognizing the progress you've made and the skills you've developed is a big step forward. It's also great that you're thinking about how to apply these skills in different areas of your life. Let's explore that a bit more. Can you give me an example of a situation where you noticed self-critical thoughts coming up in a social setting or while engaging in a hobby?

Patient: Sure. Last week, I was at my LGBTQ+ support group, and we were doing an art activity together. I was working on a painting, but I kept getting frustrated with myself because it wasn't turning out how I wanted it to. I started thinking things like, "I'm not a real artist" and "Everyone else's paintings look so much better than mine."

Therapist: That's a great example. Thank you for sharing that. I can see how those self-critical thoughts could really impact your enjoyment of the activity and your interactions with others in the group. Let's break this down using the CBT triangle. What emotions did you notice coming up as you were having those thoughts?

Patient: I felt really discouraged and frustrated with myself. I also felt a bit embarrassed, like everyone else could see that my painting wasn't good enough.

Therapist: And how did those emotions influence your behavior in that moment?

Patient: I kind of shut down and stopped participating in the conversation with the others. I just focused on my painting and tried to fix it, but I ended up feeling even more frustrated and disconnected from the group.

Therapist: That makes sense. When we get caught up in self-critical thoughts, it can really impact our emotions and behaviors, creating a cycle that's hard to break out of. Let's see if we can identify any cognitive distortions in those thoughts you shared. I noticed a bit of all-or-nothing thinking in the statement, "I'm not a real artist." It's like you're seeing things in black-and-white terms, rather than acknowledging the middle ground. What do you think about that?

Patient: Yeah, I can see that. It's like I'm putting all this pressure on myself to be perfect at everything, including art, and if I'm not perfect, then I'm not good enough at all.

Therapist: Exactly. And that kind of thinking can be really limiting and discouraging. Another distortion I noticed was a bit of mind-reading in the thought, "Everyone else's paintings look so much better than mine." It's like you're assuming you know what others are thinking, even though they didn't say anything critical about your painting. Does that resonate with you?

Patient: Definitely. I do that a lot, assuming that others are judging me, even though I don't really have evidence for that.

Therapist: That's a great insight. So, let's see if we can come up with some alternative thoughts that might be more balanced and helpful in that situation. What's another way you could look at your painting and the experience of creating it?

Patient: I guess I could remind myself that art is subjective, and everyone has their own unique style. Just because my painting doesn't look like someone else's doesn't mean it's not valuable or worthwhile.

Therapist: That's a great alternative perspective! Focusing on the value of self-expression and creativity, rather than comparison or perfectionism. How do you think your emotions and behaviors might have been different if you had been able to access that thought in the moment?

Patient: I think I would have felt less discouraged and more connected to the group. I might have been able to enjoy the process more and even share my painting with others, instead of shutting down and isolating myself.

Therapist: That's really powerful, Emilio. Being able to catch those self-critical thoughts and reframe them can make a big difference in how we feel and how we engage with the world around us. And the more you practice, the more automatic it will become. I'm curious, how might you apply this skill of reframing self-critical thoughts to other areas of your life, like work or relationships?

Patient: I think I could use it at work when I'm feeling like I'm not doing a good enough job or when I make a mistake. Instead of getting stuck in all-or-nothing thinking, I could try to focus on the things I'm doing well and remind myself that everyone makes mistakes sometimes. And in relationships, I could try to challenge those thoughts of "I'm not good enough" or "They're going to reject me" by focusing on my own worth and the value I bring to the connection.

Therapist: Those are fantastic applications of the skill, Emilio. I love how you're thinking about generalizing these tools to different areas of your life. And remember, it's okay if it feels challenging at first. The key is to keep practicing and being compassionate with yourself along the way. How are you feeling about all of this?

Patient: I'm feeling encouraged and a bit more confident. It's helpful to see how I can use these skills in different situations, and to remember that it's a process. I know I won't always get it right, but I feel like I have some good tools to keep working with.

Therapist: That's wonderful to hear, Emilio. You're doing an amazing job of integrating these skills and insights. And you're absolutely right, it's a process, and it's okay to take it one step at a time. Remember to give yourself credit for the progress you've made and the effort you're putting in. As we continue working together, we'll keep exploring how to apply these tools in different contexts and how to maintain your progress over time. How does that sound?

Patient: That sounds really good. I feel like I'm starting to see how this can really make a difference in my life, and I'm excited to keep practicing and learning.

Therapist: I'm excited to keep working with you too, Emilio. Your dedication and openness to this process is really inspiring. Let's keep building on this momentum and see where it takes us. For our next session, I'd like to continue exploring how to apply these skills in different areas of your life and how to maintain your progress over time. We can also start thinking about how to prepare for the eventual end of our sessions and how to continue supporting yourself independently. How does that sound for our plan?
